qas.question: Which term meaning "the mother book" does the Quran apply to itself?
What term is used in the Quran to indicate previous revelations?
What is the Arabic term commonly used to refer to works like the Torah or the Gospels?
What is an English translation of huda?
Which term meaning "the mother book" doesn't the Quran apply to itself?
What term is unused in the Quran to indicate previous revelations?
What term is used in the Quran to indicate future revelations?
What isn't an English translation of huda?

context: The Quran describes itself as "the discernment" (al-furqān), "the mother book" (<a0_0><b4_0>umm al-kitāb<b4_0/><a0_0/>), "<a3_0><b7_0>the guide<b7_0/><a3_0/>" (huda), "the wisdom" (hikmah), "the remembrance" (dhikr) and "the revelation" (tanzīl; something sent down, signifying the descent of an object from a higher place to lower place). Another term is <a2_0><b5_0><b6_0>al-kitāb<b6_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/> (The Book), though it is also used in the Arabic language for other scriptures, such as the Torah and the Gospels. The adjective of "Quran" has multiple transliterations including "quranic", "koranic", and "qur'anic", or capitalised as "Qur'anic", "Koranic", and "Quranic". The term <a1_0>mus'haf<a1_0/> ('written work') is often used to refer to particular Quranic manuscripts but is also used in the Quran to identify earlier revealed books. Other transliterations of "Quran" include "al-Coran", "Coran", "Kuran", and "al-Qurʼan".
